fields.headline: Reading matter
fields.bodyText: Different strokes In swimwear, one Turkish company is fast making its mark with pious Muslims across the world. Istanbul-based Hasema has been manufacturing Islamic-style swimwear. For men, these are baggy, mid-calf-length bathing trunks, which, according to Hasema's founder, Mehmet Sahin, 'don't outline one's privates'. For women, they are Spiderman-type bodysuits with tight-fitting bonnets to cover the hair. The Economist, 4-10 March The decibels, the decibels ... In a recent study, researchers found that people who live in noisy areas are far more likely to suffer a heart attack. The risk went up by about 50 per cent in men. For women, the increase was 300 per cent. All it takes to make a difference is prolonged exposure to noise in the 65- to 75-decibel range. Normal conversation is about 60 decibels, so if you have to repeatedly raise your voice to be heard, you're in an unhealthy noise environment. Environmental noise stresses the paraysympathetic system, your subconscious autopilot that continuously surveys the world around you and creates your response. US Esquire, March 2006 Land of hope and glory At the end of the Second World War, one of Franklin Roosevelt's closest advisers, Henry Morgenthau, drew up a plan that eerily paralleled in some respects Himmler's vision of the future. As the US secretary of the treasury, Morgenthau also proposed stripping Germany of its industrial might and transforming it into an agrarian nation. 'Germany's road to peace,' wrote Morgenthau in 1945, 'leads to the farm. The men and women of the German labour force can best serve themselves by cultivating the soil.' The emerging Cold War swept aside the plan. Roosevelt's successor, Harry Truman, feared stripping Germany of industrial power would fatally weaken a country viewed by some as a bulwark against Bolshevism. History Magazine, March 2006
